sp.p: Hey-dey! what's the meaning of this? Who is it went out of the room there? Have you and my daughter been in conference, Mr. Harman?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, faith, Sir; ſhe has been taking me to taſk here, very ſeverely, with regard to this affair; and ſhe has ſaid ſo much againſt it, and put it into ſuch a ſtrange light—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A buſy, impertinent baggage; egad, I wiſh I had catched her meddling, and after I ordered her not! but you have ſent to the girl, and you ſay ſhe is ready to go with you; you muſt not diſappoint her now.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no, Colonel; I always have politeneſs enough to hear a lady's reaſons; but conſtancy enough to keep a will of my own.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Very well; now let me aſk you,—don't you think it would be proper, upon this occaſion, to have a letter ready writ for the father, to let him know who has got his daughter, and ſo forth?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir; and I'll write it directly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
You write it! you be damn'd! I won't truſt you with it; I tell you, Harman, you'll commit ſome curſed blunder, if you don't leave the management of
this whole affair to me: I have writ the letter for you myſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Have you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay—here, read it; I think its the thing: however, you are welcome to make any alteration.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: "Sir, I have loved your daughter a great while, ſecretly; ſhe aſſures me ther is no hopes of your conſenting to our marriage; I therefore take her without it. I am a gentleman who will uſe her well; and, when you conſider the matter, I dare ſwear you will be willing to give her a fortune. If not, you ſhall find I dare behave myſelf like a man: a word to the wiſe. You muſt expect to hear from me in another ſtyle."

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, will it do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bravo, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As ſoon as you have got off with the girl, then ſend your ſervant back to leave it at the houſe, with orders to have it deliver'd to the old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Upon my honour, I will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And now, Sir, look into the court yonder; there's a chaiſe, Sir, and four of the prettieſt bay geldings in England for you, Sir, with two boys in ſcarlet and ſilver jackets that will whiſk you along—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Boys! Colonel? little Cupids, to tranſport me to the ſummit of my deſires.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, but for all that, it mayn't be amiſs for me to talk to them a little for you—Dick, come hither—you are to go with this gentleman, and do whatever he bids you; and take into the chaiſe whoever he pleaſes; and drive like devils, do you hear; but, be kind to the dumb beaſts.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Leave that to me, Sir—And ſo, my dear Colonel, bon voyage!

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Colonel OLDBOY, Lady MARY, and then JENNY.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Mr. Oldboy, here is a note from Sir John Flowerdale; it is addreſs'd to me, intreating my ſon to come over there again this morning. A maid brought it: ſhe is in the anti-chamber—We had better ſpeak to her—Child, child, why don't you come in?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I chuſe to ſtay where I am, if your Ladyſhip pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Stay where you are! why ſo?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I am afraid of the old gentleman there.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Afraid of me, huſſy?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Pray, Colonel, have patience—Afraid! Here is ſomething at the bottom of this.—What did you mean by that expreſſion, child?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Why the Colonel knows very well, Madam, he wanted to be rude with me yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Oldboy!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Lady Mary, don't provoke me, but let me talk to the girl about her buſineſs.—How come you to bring this note here?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Why, Sir John gave it to me, to deliver to my uncle Jenkins, and I took it down to his houſe; but while we were talking together, he remembered that he had ſome buſineſs with Sir John, ſo he deſired me to bring it; becauſe he ſaid it was not proper to be ſent by any of the common ſervants.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Colonel, look in my face, and help bluſhing, if you can.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What the plague's the matter, my Lady? I have not been wronging you now, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lady, he offered to make me his kept madam: I am ſure his uſage of me put me into ſuch a twitter, that I did not know what I was doing all the day after.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I don't doubt it, though I ſo lately forgave him; but as the poet ſays, His ſex is all deceit. Read Pamela, child, and reſiſt temptation.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why I tell you, my Lady, it was all a joke.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No, Sir, it was no joke, you made me a proffer of money, ſo you did; whereby I told you, you had a Lady of your own, and that though ſhe was old, you had no right to deſpiſe her.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And how dare you, miſtreſs, make uſe of my name? Is it for ſuch trollops as you to talk of perſons of diſtinction behind their backs?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Why, Madam, I only ſaid you was in years.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Sir John Flowerdale ſhall be inform'd of your impertinence, and you ſhall be turn'd out of the family; I ſee you are a confident creature, and I believe no better than you ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I ſcorn your words, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Get out of the room; how dare you ſtay in this room to talk impudently to me?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Very well, Madam, I ſhall let my Lady know how you have us'd me; but I ſhan't be turn'd out oſ my place, Madam; nor at a loſs, if I am; and if you are angry with every one that won't fay you are young, I believe there is very few you will keep friends with.

l.hi: I wonder, I'm ſure, why this fuſs ſhould be made;
F • r my part I'm neither aſham'd nor afraid
Of what I have done, nor of what I have ſaid.
A ſervant, I hope, is no ſlave;
I know better how to behave.
Nor my character ſuch I need ſtarve on't:
And ſo I'm your Ladyſhip's ſervant.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Colonel OLDBOY, Lady MARY, Mr. JESSAMY.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: What is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I will have a ſeparate maintenance, I will indeed. Only a new inſtance of your father's infidelity, my dear. Then with ſuch low wretches, farmer's daughters and ſervant wenches: but any thing with a cap on, 'tis all the ſame to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I am ſorry to tell you, that thoſe practices very ill ſuit the character which you ought to endeavour to ſupport in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Is this a recompence for my love and regard; I, who have been tender and faithful as a turtle dove?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: A man of your birth and diſtinction ſhould, methinks, have views of a higher nature, than ſuch low, ſuch vulgar libertiniſm.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Conſider my birth and family too—Lady Mary Jeſſamy might have had the beſt matches in England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Then, Sir, your grey hairs.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I, that have brought you ſo many lovely ſweet babes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it is a reflection on me.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: The heinous ſin too!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I bluſh for you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and fire, you little effeminate puppy, do you know who you talk to?—And you, Madam, do you know who I am?—Get up to your chamber, or zounds I'll make ſuch a—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Ah! my dear, come away from him.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Colonel OLDBOY, Mr. JESSAMY, a Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Am I to be tutor'd, and call'd to an account!—How now, you ſcoundrel, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A letter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A letter! from whom, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The gentleman's ſervant, an't pleaſe your honour, that left this juſt now in the poſt-chaiſe—the gentleman my young lady went away with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your young lady, ſirrah—Your young lady went away with no gentleman, you dog—What gentleman! What young lady, ſirrah!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: There is ſome myſtery in this—With your leave, Sir, I'll open the letter: I believe it contains no ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What are you going to do, you jackanapes? you ſhan't open a letter of mine—Dy—Diana!—Somebody call my daughter to me there—"To John Oldboy, Eſq.—Sir, I have lov'd your daughter a great while ſecretly—Conſenting to our marriage"

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You villain—you dog, what is it you have brought me here?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, if you'll have patience, I'll tell your honour—As I told your honour before, the gentleman's ſervant that went off juſt now in the poſt-chaiſe, come to the gate, and left it after his maſter was gone. I ſaw my young lady go into the chaiſe with the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: A very fine joke indeed! pray, Colonel, do you generally write letters to yourſelf? Why this is your own hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Call all the ſervants in the houſe, let horſes be ſaddled directly—every one take a different road.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why, your honour, Dick ſaid it was by your own orders.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My orders! you raſcal? I thought he was going to run away with another gentleman's daughter—Dy—Diana Oldboy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Don't waſte your lungs to no purpoſe, Sir; your daughter is half a dozen miles off by this time.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sirrah, you have been brib'd to further the ſcheme of a pick-pocket here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Beſides, the matter is entirely of your own contriving, as well as the letter and ſpirit of this elegant epiſtle.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are a coxcomb, and I'll diſinherit you; the letter is none of my writing; it was writ by the devil, and the devil contrived it. Diana, Margaret, my Lady Mary, William, John!—

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: I am very glad of this, prodigiouſly glad of it, upon my honour—he! he! he!—it will be a jeſt this hundred years. (bells ringing violently on both ſides.) What's the matter now? O! her Ladyſhip has heard of it, and is at her bell; and the Colonel anſwers her. A pretty duet; but a little too much upon the fortè methinks: it would be a diverting thing now, to ſtand unſeen at the old gentleman's elbow.

lg.l: Hiſt, ſoft; let's hear how matters go;
I'll creep and liſten;—ſo, ſo, ſo,
They're all together by the ears;—
Oh, horrid! how the ſavage ſwears.
There too again; ay, you may ring:
Sound out th' alarm-bell—ding, ding, ding—
Diſpatch your ſcouts, 'tis all in vain,
Stray maids are ſeldom found again.
But hark, the uprcar hither ſounds;
The Colonel comes with all his hounds;
I'll wiſely leave them open way,
To hunt with what ſucceſs they may.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Calonel OLDBOY re-enters, with one Boot, a Great-coat, on his Arm, &c. followed by ſeveral Servants.
div.p: She's gone, by the Lord! fairly ſlole away, with that poaching, concy-catching raſcal!. However, I won't follow her; no, damme; take my whip, and my cap, and my coat, and order the groom to unſaddle the horſes; I won't follow her the length of a ſpur-leather. Come here, you Sir, and pull off my boot; (whiſtles) ſhe has made a fool of me once, ſhe ſhan't do it a ſecond time; not but I'll be reveng'd too, for I'll never give her ſixpence; the diſappointment will put the ſcoundrel out of temper, and he'll thraſh her a dozen times a-day; the thought pleaſes me; I hope be'll do it.
What do you ſtand gaping and ſtaring at, you impudent dogs? are you laughing at me? I'll teach you to be merry at my expence.—

lg.l: A raſcal, a haſſey; zounds! ſhe that I counted
In temper ſo mild, ſo unpractis'd in evil;
I ſet her a horſe-back, and no ſooner mounted,
Than, crack, whip and ſpur, ſhe rides poſt to the devil.
But there let her run,
Be ruin'd, undone;
If I go to catch her,
Or back again fetch her.
I'm worſe than the ſon of a gun.
A miſchief poſſeſs'd me to marry:
And further my folly to carry.
To be ſtill more a ſot,
Sons and daughters I got,
And pretty ones, by the L •• d Harry:

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Changes to CLARISSA's Dreſſing-room; CLARISSA enters melancholy, with a Book in her Hand, followed by JENNY.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Where have you been, Jenny? I was enquiring for you—why will you go out without letting me know?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Dear Ma'am, never any thing happen'd ſo unlucky; I am ſorry you wanted me—But I was ſent to Colonel Oldboy's with a letter; where I have been ſo uſed—Lord have mercy upon me—quality indeed—I ſay quality—pray, Madam, do you think that I looks any ways like an immodeſt parſon—to be ſure I have a gay air, and I can't help it, and I loves to appear a little genteeliſh, that's what I do.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Jenny, take away this book.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Heaven preſerve me, Madam! you are crying;

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O my dear Jenny!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My dear miſtreſs, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No, Madam; no, Lord forbid!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am indeed—I have been raſh enough to diſcover my weakneſs for a man, who treats me with contempt.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is Mr. Lionel ungrateful, then?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I have loſt his eſteem for ever, Jenny. Since laſt night, that I fatally confeſs'd what I ſhould have kept a ſecret from all the world, he has ſcarce condeſcended to caſt a look at me, nor given me an anſwer, when I ſpoke to him, but with coldneſs and reſerve.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Then he is a naſty, barbarous, unhuman brute.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold, Jenny, hold; it is all my fault.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Your fault, Madam! I wiſh I was to hear ſuch a word come out of his mouth: if he was a miniſter to-morrow, and to ſay ſuch a thing from his pulpit, and I by, I'd tell him it was falſe upon the ſpot.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Somebody's at the door; ſee who it is.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: You in fault indeed!—that I know to be the moſt virtuouſeſt, niceſt, moſt delicateſt—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Madam, it's a meſſage from Mr. Lionel. If you are alone, and at leiſure, he would be glad to wait upon you: I'll tell him, Madam, that you're buſy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Where is he, Jenny!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: In the ſtudy, the man ſays.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Then go to him, and tell him I ſhould be glad to ſee him: but do not bring him up immediately, becauſe I will ſtand in the balcony a few minutes for a little air.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Do ſo, dear Madam, for your eyes are as red as ferret's; you are ready to faint too; mercy on us, for what do you grieve and vex yourſelf?—if I was as you—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh!

lg.l: Why with ſighs my heart is ſwelling,
Why with tears my eyes o'erflow,
Aſk me not; 'tis paſt the telling,
Mute, involuntary woe.
Who to winds and waves a ſtranger,
Vent'rous tempts the inconſtant ſeas,
In each billow fancies danger,
Shrinks at every riſing breeze.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE, JENKINS.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: So then, the myſtery is diſcovered:—but is it poſſible that my daughter's refuſal of Colonel Oldboy's ſon ſhould procced from a clandeſtine engagement, and that engagement with Lionel?

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: My niece, Sir, is in her young Lady's ſecrets, and Lord knows ſhe had little deſign to betray them; but having remarked ſome odd expreſſions of her's yeſterday, when ſhe came down to me this morning with the letter, I queſtioned her; and, in ſhort, drew the whole affair out; upon which I feigned a recollection of ſome buſineſs with you, and deſired her to carry the letter to Colonel Oldboy's herſelf, while I came up hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: And they are mutually promiſed to each other, and that promiſe was exchanged yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and it is my duty to tell you; elſe I would rather die than be the means of wounding the heart of my dear young lady: for if there is one upon earth of truly noble and delicate ſentiments—

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I thought ſo once, Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: And think ſo ſtill: O good Sir John, now is the time for you to exert that character of worth and gentleneſs which the world ſo deſervedly has given you. You have indeed cauſe to be offended; but conſider, Sir, your daughter is young, beautiful, and amiable; the poor youth unexperienced, ſenſible, and at a time of life when ſuch temptations are hard to be reſiſted; their opportunities were many, their caſt of thinking the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Jenkins, I can allow for all theſe things; but the young hypocrites—There's the thing, Jenkins; their hypocriſy, their hypocriſy wounds me.

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Call it by a gentler name, Sir; modeſty on her part, apprehenſion on his.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Then what opportunity have they had? They never were together but when my ſiſter or myſelf made one of the company; beſides, I had ſo firm a reliance on Lionel's honour and gratitude—

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Sir, I can never think that Nature ſtamp'd that gracious countenance of his, to maſk a corrupt heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: How! at the very time that he was conſcious of being himſelf the cauſe of it, did he not ſhew more concern at this affair than I did? Nay, don't I tell you that laſt night, of his own accord, he offered to be a mediator in the affair, and deſired my leave to ſpeak to my daughter? I thought myſelf obliged to him, conſented; and in conſequence of his aſſurance of ſucceſs, wrote that letter to Colonel Oldboy, to deſire the family would come here again to-day.

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Sir, as we were ſtanding in the next room, I heard a meſſage delivered from Mr. Lionel, deſiring leave to wait upon your daughter; I dare ſwear they will be here preſently; ſuppoſe we were to ſtep into that cloſet, and overhear their converſation?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: What, Jenkins, after having lived ſo many years in confidence with my child, ſhall I become an eves-dropper to detect her?

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: It is neceſſary at preſent.—Come in, my dear maſter, let us only conſider that we were once young like them; ſubject to the ſame paſſions, the ſame indiſcretions; and it is the duty of every man to pardon errors incident to his kind.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: CLARISSA, LIONEL.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, you deſired to ſpeak to me; I need not tell you the preſent ſituation of my heart; it is full. Whatever you have to ſay, I beg you will explain yourſelf; and, if poſſible, rid me of the anxiety under which I have laboured for ſome hours.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Madam, your anxiety cannot be greater than mine; I come, indeed, to ſpeak to you; and yet, I know not how; I come to adviſe you, ſhall I ſay as a friend? yes, as a friend to your glory, your felicity; dearer to me than my life.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Sir John Flowerdale, Madam, is ſuch a father as few are bleſſed with; his care, his prudence has provided for you a match.—Your refuſal renders him inconſolable. Liſten to no ſuggeſtions that would pervert you from your duty, but make the worthieſt of men happy by ſubmitting to his will.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How, Sir, after what paſſed between us yeſterday evening, can you adviſe me to marry Mr. Jeſſamy?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I would adviſe you to marry any one, Madam, rather than a villain.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A villain, Sir!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I ſhould be the worſt of villains, Madam, was I to talk to you in any other ſtrain: Nay, am I not a villain, at once treacherous and ungrateful? Received into this houſe as an aſylum; what have I done! Betrayed the confidence of a friend that truſted me; endeavoured to ſacrifice his peace, and the honour of his family, to my own unwarrantable deſires.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Say no more, Sir; ſay no more; I ſee my error too late; I have parted from the rules preſcribed to my ſex; I have miſtaken indecorum for a laudable ſincerity; and it is juſt I ſhould meet with the treatment my imprudence deſerves.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: 'Tis I, only I, am to blame; while I took advantage of the father's ſecurity, I practiſed upon the tenderneſs and ingenuity of the daughter; my own imagination gone aſtray, I artfully laboured to lead yours after it: but here, Madam, I give you back thoſe vows which I inſidiouſly extorted from you; keep them for ſome happier man, who may receive them without wounding his honour, or his peace.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Don't ſpeak to me.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Oh! my Clariſſa, my heart is broke; I am hateful to myſelf for loving you; yet, before I leave you for ever, I will once more touch that lovely hand—indulge my fondneſs with a laſt look—pray for your health and proſperity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Can you forſake me? Have I then given my affections to a man who rejects and diſregards them?—Let me throw myſelf at my father's feet; he is generous and compaſſionate:—He knows your worth—

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Farewell, farewell!

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: CLARISSA, JENNY, then Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE and JENKINS; and afterwards LIONEL.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: O Madam! I have betray'd you. I have gone and ſaid ſomething I ſhould not have ſaid to my uncle Jenkins; and, as ſure as day, he has gone and told it all to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Go, Jenkins, and deſire that young gentleman to come back—ſtay where you are—But what have I done to you, my child? How have I deſerv'd that you ſhould treat me like an enemy? Has there been any undeſigned rigour in my conduct, or terror in my looks?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Lionel.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Come in—When I tell you that I am inſtructed in all your proceedings, and that I have been ear-witneſs to your converſation in this place; you will, perhaps, imagine what my thoughts are of you, and the meaſures which juſtice preſcribes me to follow.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to ſay in my own defence; I ſtand before you, ſelf-convicted, ſelf-condemn'd, and ſhall ſubmit without murmuring to the ſentence of my judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p:
As for you, Clariſſa, ſince your earlieſt infancy, you have known no parent but me; I have been to you, at once, both father and mother; and, that I might the better fulfill thoſe united duties, tho' left a widower in the prime of my days, I would never enter into a ſecond marriage.—I loved you for your likeneſs to your dear mother: but that mother never
deceiv'd me—and there the likeneſs fails—you have repaid my affection with diſſimulation—Clariſſa, you ſhould have truſted me.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: O my dear, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: As for you, Mr. Lionel, what terms can I find ſtrong enough to paint the exceſs of my friendſhip?—I loved, I eſteemed, I honoured your father: he was a brave, a generous, and a ſincere man; I thought you inherited his good qualities—you were left an orphan, I adopted you, put you upon the footing of my own ſon; educated you like a gentleman; and deſign'd you for a profeſſion, to which, I thought, your virtues would have been an ornament.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Dear me, dear me.

sp.speaker: Jenk.
sp.p: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: What return you have made me, you ſeem to be acquainted with yourſelf; and, therefore, I ſhall not repeat it—Yet, remember as an aggravation of your guilt, that the laſt mark of my bounty was conferr'd upon you in the very inſtant, when you were undermining my deſigns. Now, Sir, I have but one thing more to ſay to you—Take my daughter; was ſhe worth millions, ſhe is at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To me, Sir!—your daughter!—do you give her to me? Without fortune—without friends—without—

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: You have them all in your heart; him whom virtue raiſes, fortune cannot abaſe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O, Sir, let me on my knees kiſs that dear hand—acknowledge my error, and intreat forgiveneſs and bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: You have not erred, my dear daughter; you have diſtinguiſh'd. It is I ſhould aſk pardon, for this little trial of you; for I am happier in the ſon-in-law you have given me, than if you had married a prince.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
My patron—my friend—my father—I would
fain ſay ſomething; but, as your goodneſs exceeds all bounds—

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I think I hear a coach drive into the court; it is Colonel Oldboy's family; I will go and receive them. Don't make yourſelves uneaſy at this; we muſt endeavour to pacify them as well as we can. My dear Lionel, if I have made you happy, you have made me ſo; Heaven bleſs you, my children, and make you deſerving of one another.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: CLARISSA, LIONEL, JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: O dear, Madam, upon my knees, I humbly beg your pardon: dear Mr. Lionel, forgive me: I did not deſign to diſcover it, indeed: and you won't turn me off, Madam, will you? I'll ſerve you for nothing.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Getup, my good Jenny; I freely forgive you, if there is any thing to be forgiven. I know you love me; and, I am ſure here is one who will join with me in rewarding your ſevices.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, if I did not know, as ſure as could be, that ſome good would happen, by my left eye itching this morning.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: O bliſs unexpected! my joys overpower me!
My love, my Clariſſa, what words ſhall I find!
Remorſe, deſperation, no longer devour me—
He bleſs'd us, and peace is reſtor'd to my mind▪

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He bleſs'd us! O rapture! Like one I recover,
Whom death had appal'd without hope, without aid;
A moment reſtores, and my pangs are repaid.

lg.l: But pain was inflicted by Heaven, out of kindneſs,
To heighten the joys that were doom'd to ſucceed.
Our day was o'ercaſt:
But brighter the ſcene is,
The ſky more ſerene is,
And ſofter the calm for the hurricane paſt.

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: Changes to the Hall. Lady MARY OLDBOY leaning on a Servant, Mr. JESSAMY leading her; JENNY; and afterwards, Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE with Colonel OLDBOY.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain, my dear;—ſet me down any where; I can't go a ſtep further—I knew, when Mr. Oldboy inſiſted upon my coming, that I ſhould be ſeized with a meagrim by the way; and it's well I did not die in the coach.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: But, pr'ythee, why will you let yourſelf be affected with ſuch trifles?—Nothing more common than for young women of faſhion to go off with low fellows!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Only feel, my dear, how I tremble! Not a nerve but what is in agitation; and my blood runs cold, cold!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Well, but, Lady Mary, don't let us expoſe ourſelves to thoſe people; I ſee there is not one of the raſcals about us, that has not a grin upon his countenance.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Expoſe ourſelves! my dear? Your father will be as ridiculous as Hudibras, or Don Quixote.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I give you my word, my good friend, and neighbour, the joy I feel upon this occaſion, is greatly allayed by the diſappointment of an aliance with your family; but I have explained to you how things have happened—You ſee my ſituation; and, as you are kind enough to conſider it yourſelf, I hope you will excuſe it to your ſon.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Sir John Flowerdale, how do you do? You ſee we have obey'd your ſummons; and I have the pleaſure to aſſure you, that my ſon yielded to my intreaties with very little diſagreement: in ſhort, if I may ſpeak metaphorically, he is content to ſtand candidate again, notwithſtanding his late repulſe, when he hopes for an unanimous election.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, but, my Lady, you may ſave your rhetoric: ▪for the borough is diſpoſed of to a worthier member.

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE, Lady MARY, Mr. JESSAMY, Celonel OLDBOY, LIONEL, CLARISSA, JENNY.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Here are my ſon and daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Is this pretty, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, it is not for want of a juſt ſenſe of Mr. Jeſſamy's merit, that this affair has gone off on any ſide: but the heart is a delicate thing; and after it has once felt, if the object is meritorious, the impreſſion is not eaſily effac'd; it would therefore have been an injury to him, to have given him in appearance what another in reality poſſeſſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Upon my honour, upon my ſoul, Sir John, I am not the leaſt offended at this contre temps—Pray, Lady Mary, ſay no more about it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Tol, lol, lol, lol.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p:
But my dear Colonel, I am afraid, after
all, this affair is taken amiſs by you: yes, I ſee you are angry on your ſon's account; but let me repeat it, I have a very high opinion of his merit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay! that's more than I have. Taken amiſs! I don't take any thing amiſs; I never was in better ſpirits, or more pleaſed in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Come, you are uneaſy at ſomething, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Me! Gad I am not uneaſy—Are you a juſtice of peace! Then you could give me a warrant, cou'dn't you? You muſt know, Sir John, a little accident has happen'd in my family ſince I ſaw you laſt; you and I may ſhake hands—Daughters, Sir, daughters! Your's has ſnapt at a young fellow without your approbation; and how do you think mine has ſerv'd me this morning?—Only run away with the ſcoundrel I brought to dinner here yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I am exceſſively concerned.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Now I'm not a bit concern'd—No, dam'me, I am glad it has happened! yet, thus far, I'll confeſs, I ſhould be ſorry that either of them would come in my way, becauſe a man's temper may ſometimes get the better of him: and I believe I ſhould be tempted to break her neck, and blow his brains out.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, explain this affair.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can explain it no farther—Dy, my daughter Dy, has run away from us.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE, Colonel OLDBOY, Lady MARY OLDBOY, Mr. JESSAMY, CLARISSA, LIONEL, DIANA, HARMAN.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: No, my dear papa, I am not run away; and upon my knees, I intreat your pardon for the folly I have committed; but, let it be ſome alleviation, that duty, affection, were too ſtrong to ſuffer me to carry it to extremity: and, if you knew the agony I have been in ſince I ſaw you laſt—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, I reſtore your daughter to you; whoſe fault, as far as it goes, I muſt alſo take upon myſelf; we have been known to each other ſome time; as Lady Richly, your ſiſter, in London, can acquaint you—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Dy, come here—Now, you raſcal, where's • our ſword; if you are a gentleman, you ſhall fight me; if you are a ſcrub, I'll horſe-whip you—Draw, Sirrah—Shut the door there, don't let him eſcape.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, don't imagine I want to eſcape; I am extremely ſorry for what has happened, but am ready to give you any ſatisfaction you think proper.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Follow me into the garden then—Zounds! I have no ſword about me—Sir John Flowerdale—lend us a caſe of piſtols, or a couple of guns; and come and ſee fair play.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My dear papa!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Sir John Flowerdale—O my indiſcretion—we came here, Sir, to beg your mediation in our favour.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Mr. Oldboy, if you attempt to fight, I hall expire.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Pray, Colonel, let me ſpeak a word to you in private.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Slugs and a ſaw-pit—

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: Why, Miſs Dy, you are a perfect heroine for a romance—And, pray who is this courteous knight?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: O Sir, you that I thought ſuch a pretty behav'd gentleman!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: What buſineſs are you of, friend?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My chief trade, Sir, is plain dealing; and, as that is a commodity you have no reaſon to be very fond of, I would not adviſe you to purchaſe any of it by impertinence.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And is this what you would adviſe me to?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: It is, indeed, my dear old friend; as things are ſituated, there is, in my opinion, no other prudent method of proceeding; and it is the method I would adopt myſelf, was I in your caſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, I believe you are in the right of it—Say what you will for me then.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Well! young people, I have been able to uſe a few arguments, which have ſoftened my neighbour here; and in ſome meaſure pacified his reſentment. I find, Sir, you are a gentleman by your connections?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, till it is found that my character and family will bear the ſtricteſt ſcrutiny, I deſire no favour—And for fortune—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh! rot your fortune, I don't mind that—I know you are a gentleman, or Dick Rantum would not have recommended you. And ſo, Dy, kiſs and friends.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeſſ.
sp.p: What, Sir, have you no more to ſay to the man who has uſed you ſo ill?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Us'd me ill!—That's as I take it—he has done a mettled thing; and, perhaps, I like him the better for it; it's long before you would have ſpirit enough to run away with a wench—Harman, give me your hand; let's hear no more of this now.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am ſo bound by your generoſity, Sir—

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: Sir JOHN FLOWERDALE, Colonel OLDBOY, Lady MARY OLDBOY, Mr. JESSAMY, CLARISSA, LIONEL, JENNY, DIANA, HARMAN, JENKINS.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Call more people in here—Sir John Flowerdale, what ſay you? ſhall we ſpend the day together, and dedicate it to love and harmony?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then take off my great-coat.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Come then, all ye ſocial pow'rs,
Crown with bliſs the preſent hours,
May the juſt, the gen'rous kind,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: May, like me, each maiden wiſe,

sp.speaker: Jeſſ.
sp.l: Why the deuce ſhould men be ſad,
Grave, or gay, or vex'd, or glad,
Bring the flaſk, the muſic bring,
Drink, and laugh, and dance, and ſing,
And caſt our cares behind us.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I'll e'en curtſey, own my fault,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: One word more before we go;
You to friends muſt ſomething owe,
Still they muſt be loſt, unleſs
You lend a hand to ſave 'em.
